pros: Very good pay for part time instructors although a pay gap is increasingly widening between full time and part time instructors. Very diverse student body and faculty.
cons: There is a lack of initiative when it comes to solving long standing problems in the delivery of education. Or, if change comes it moves at a snail's pace. 1. For over a decade they have not solved the problem of giving timely access of faculty to their classrooms at some campuses. They have installed card readers on classroom doors years ago, yet faculty are not given these cards. Instead, a security guard must be called and waited for to gain access. 2. Computers in every classroom have been "coming soon" for over a decade as well. In the meantime, some of us must sign out a cart with a laptop bolted onto it and a projector and wheel it to our classroom, sometimes in another building or on another floor. Other rooms have a tiny computer mounted on the wall, but the keyboard or mouse to control it must be signed out.

pros: The main thing I can say is no one I've met has been difficult—everyone is ready and willing to help and assist. The pay is decent, and even part-timers are represented and take part in the retirement plan (that's not something you'll find everywhere). If you can feel satisfied just teaching your class and moving along with your life, then this might work for you.
cons: This has to be the most dysfunctional place I've ever worked—and I've worked for a lot of different places. There is no process, no procedure, no organization. If you need something done, you need to find the person (or maybe the persons) to get it done for you. You have to create relationships and that's the only way it gets done. If you are looking for collaboration and culture dedicated to education and support for those doing it, then this might not work for you.
